Climate change will increase the variability of global crop yields, making it more difficult to achieve food security. We quantify the magnitude of this yield variability and its consequences for global maize production and trade. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values in most major maize-producing and -exporting countries. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. The probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

We found that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest overlap in diet. This study highlights the importance of using DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth and composition in natural assemblages of herbivores. The hemoglobin system is a key component of the oxygen transport system in vertebrates. The hemoglobin system is also a target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. We show that IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional loss of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is essential for fetal hemoglobin expression. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the hemoglobin phenotypes observed in patients with hemoglobinopathies and in individuals with aging-related changes in hemoglobin expression. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The policy did halt clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area was stable, but declined in two ecoregions—the Coast Range and Cascades—along with early-seral bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the need for continued monitoring of forest conditions and bird populations to assess the effectiveness of forest management policies. This is especially important in light of the recent changes in forest ownership and management in the Pacific Northwest.

The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that this practice can have negative effects on sleep. Specifically, reading an electronic book before bedtime can delay the circadian clock, suppress melatonin, and reduce alertness the next morning. These effects are likely to be more common than currently recognized, given the increasing use of these devices.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding and the evolution of genes enabling digestion of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes enabling digestion of plant cell walls.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the durability of the current vaccine and antibody responses. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple variants, including Delta. Our results highlight the power of deep learning in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to mitigate the impact of SARS-CoV-2 variants and potentially other viruses in the future.

Our results suggest that the size of the population may be more important for the maintenance of cultural diversity than for its enhancement. This may be important for understanding the evolution of cultural diversity in natural populations and in the evolution of the human mind.

The brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels, was compared between marijuana abusers and controls. Compared with controls, marijuana abusers had significantly attenuated responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal dopamine and reductions in the brain’s reactivity to the DA stimulation. In ventral striatum (key brain reward region), MP-induced reductions in DVs and BPND (reflecting DA increases) were inversely correlated with scores of negative emotionality, which were significantly higher for marijuana abusers than controls. In marijuana abusers, DA responses in ventral striatum were also inversely correlated with addiction severity and craving. The attenuated responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal DVs, are consistent with decreased brain reactivity to the DA stimulation in marijuana abusers that might contribute to their negative emotionality (increased stress reactivity and irritability) and addictive behaviors. These findings highlight the urgency to investigate effects of chronic marijuana in the human brain.

The human brain is the most powerful computer ever built. How does it compute? A promising approach is to study the neural basis of computation across many datasets and many computational models. We take this approach to language processing, the signature cognitive ability of the human brain. We find that the most powerful models of language processing in the brain are also the most predictive of brain activity in language-processing regions. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the human brain may be built around a “transformer” architecture, which is simple yet powerful. This architecture may be a general principle of brain and cognition. Future work should test this hypothesis. In addition, the approach we take here can be extended to other domains and cognitive processes. It may thus yield new insights into the brain’s information-processing principles. It may also help to understand the brain’s computation in neuropsychiatric disorders.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in many fields, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that the instability is inherent to the problem, not to the technology. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This result has implications for the development of DL, as well as for the development of scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough and the failure of the public to comply with public health measures. One of the most prominent arguments is that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. We discuss the flaws of the experiment and show that it is not surprising that people fail to understand it. We also discuss the implications of this study for the COVID-19 pandemic and beyond.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause different forms of the disease. The two bacteria are very similar, but they are not the same species. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria have retained many of the same genes, despite having diverged from each other over 13 million years ago. This suggests that the two bacteria are still capable of causing the same disease. This is important because it means that the development of new treatments for leprosy will not be hindered by the fact that the two bacteria are different species. Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also intimately related, as revealed by the study of quantum quenches. However, the entanglement dynamics is a highly nontrivial problem, which has been studied so far only for noninteracting systems. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems, which is a highly nontrivial task. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our results are relevant for the study of quantum quenches in general, and for the understanding of the thermodynamics of interacting systems in particular.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. The ribosome is a key component of the protein synthesis machinery that is responsible for translating messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences into proteins. The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is often an important factor in attracting pollinators, but the mechanisms by which plants produce and use color in nectar are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a second alkaloid in the red nectar of Jaltomata herrerae, a hummingbird-visited species, and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of color in nectar and the role of alkaloids in this process. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages is poorly understood. We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 450 and 650 AD. The analysis of their genomes indicates that women had a very high genetic heterogeneity, which includes signals of ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides a unique opportunity to understand the genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages. It also demonstrates the power of the genome-wide association studies approach to study the genetic history of the past.

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that requires multiple proteins to assemble and function. One of the most important proteins involved in DNA replication is the sliding clamp, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). PCNA is a clamp that wraps around DNA and allows replication to occur. However, PCNA is also a protein that can bind to DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) and allow it to replicate DNA. In this study, we show that pol δ can bind to PCNA and form a holoenzyme that can replicate DNA. We also show that the pol δ holoenzyme is very stable and can remain bound to PCNA for a long time. This study provides a better understanding of the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and how it interacts with PCNA. This knowledge can be used to understand how pol δ is regulated and how it is involved in human diseases. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science, and the RNA world hypothesis has been a leading candidate for the solution. In the RNA world, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules, and replication was catalyzed by RNA enzymes. In the laboratory, RNA enzymes can be evolved to improve their activity and generality. In this paper, we report the evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including functional RNA enzymes. This polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the realization of the RNA world. (Show more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods is a key factor in the success of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can reduce mortality and improve the clinical symptoms of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, it is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess can be toxic. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is well established, but the existence of copper-binding natural products in fungi has not been demonstrated. Here we show that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. These findings suggest that fungal natural products may mediate interactions with competing microbes by controlling the availability of copper. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis in fungi and may lead to the development of novel antifungal agents. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agricultural crops. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new conditions. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is not known whether Th17 cells are required for disease or merely contribute to it. Here we show that Th17 cells are required for the development of colitis in a Th17 cell–transfer model. Th17 cells can directly induce the development of Th1-like cells, and Th17 cells can support the development of classic Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of disease pathogenesis. Thus, targeting Th17 cells may be a useful strategy for treating inflammatory bowel disease. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins and by the expansion of a repeat in a gene encoding a protein involved in RNA processing. The disease is progressive and ultimately fatal. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, enabling disease modeling and drug screening. This will accelerate the development of new therapies for ALS. This method will also be useful for studying other neurodegenerative diseases caused by mutations in motor neuron genes. The gut microbiota of ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the gut microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of the tick. We demonstrate that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, which alters the permeability of the gut and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen appropriates an antibacterial protein from an arthropod to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work also provides a framework for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of life. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is obscured by the limited known diversity of early branching pygostylians. Here, we describe a basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China that adds important information about early members of the short-tailed bird group. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the avian flight apparatus. (Show more)

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding its components. In this paper, we show that stratospheric water vapor is an important component of the climate system. We show that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, and we estimate the strength of this relationship. We also show that the increase in stratospheric water vapor is due to the increase in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer. This finding is important because it shows that the tropical tropopause layer is an important region for the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, due to the presence of pigments in their tissues. However, some vertebrates have distinctive blue-green colors, which are caused by unusually high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally present in the blood. We show that the occurrence of high biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of serpin family proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study contributes to our understanding of the biochemical basis, biology, and evolution of chlorosis. Additionally, our findings have implications for the study of the evolution of color in vertebrates.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, and is associated with increased tumorigenicity and metastasis. However, the mechanisms that regulate the hypoxic phenotype in breast cancer are not well understood. We show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a breast cancer stem cell factor. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the HIF-1α and HIF-2α pathways. NANOG expression is increased in a NANOG 3′-UTR-dependent manner, and ALKBH5 mutation in this region abrogates this effect. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in response to hypoxia is a mechanism that regulates the breast cancer stem cell phenotype. This study provides a mechanism for the induction of the hypoxic phenotype in breast cancer. It also provides a rationale for the use of ALKBH5 inhibitors in the treatment of breast cancer. The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The source of the parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles is still unknown. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment from the past. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of extinction and recovery. We present a new age model for the Permian-Triassic boundary based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age model shows that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the recovery was protracted. These results are important for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction and recovery of the end-Permian biota. They also provide a critical time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in circulating variants and is thought to increase infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike in the D614 and G614 conformations and show that the G614 spike is more open and may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion. These results provide insights into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may inform the development of vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an equilibrium, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite. The proof is based on a new method for constructing equilibria in stochastic games.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y for 2020. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms, which can be seen as the first- and second-order chemical potentials. We calculate, as a function of pressure, these two properties and find that they decrease with pressure, consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of matter under pressure. It is also a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of matter in the core of stars. Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can alter the carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of this effect is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between climate, fire, and carbon. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression can reduce the warming caused by greenhouse gases. This effect is most pronounced under lower emissions scenarios, and it could reduce global warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to manage fire in a way that is consistent with other ecosystem services.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by nature to maintain the health of the host. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan-provisioning strategy may be used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes.

The study of topics in text is a central problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method that integrates two recent advances in machine learning: topic modeling and word embedding. Our method can be applied to any corpus of text, and it can be extended to other types of data. We illustrate our method with a prominent example: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. It can be extended to other types of data, and it can be applied to other domains. We believe that it will be a useful tool for researchers and practitioners in many fields.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague and its spread, and it has implications for the study of the spread of other diseases in the past. The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases to affect the sea stars of the world. The disease is caused by a virus that has spread rapidly throughout the affected populations. We have identified the virus and shown that it is the likely cause of the disease. This is a major step forward in understanding the disease and in developing control strategies.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis of AML is poor. The identification of AML stem cells is important for the development of more efficient therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample genomic diversity across the island, and we found that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, with a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in the Malagasy population. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia happened independently. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This is important for the interpretation of genomic data from Madagascar and other islands. Our results also suggest that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased manner, which is consistent with the idea that the first settlers were men.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a protein that interacts with a membrane-bound enzyme and increases its activity. We also show that the RNA base pairs with the promoter of two other genes and that the base pairing interferes with the RNA’s ability to repress the genes. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate multiple biological processes. The RNA is also an example of a small protein that has evolved to interact with a membrane-bound enzyme. This is a rare example of a protein that has evolved to interact with a membrane-bound enzyme. The dual-function RNA and protein are examples of the diversity of roles that small RNAs can play in bacteria.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the durability of the current vaccine and antibody responses. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple variants, including Delta. Our results highlight the power of deep learning in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to ensure the durability of the human immune response against SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can also provide a proof-of-concept for the application of deep learning in antibody engineering. This approach can be extended to other protein molecules, such as enzymes and receptors. This work can also be extended to other applications in drug discovery, such as the optimization of drug candidates against variants. Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their assessments are critical for monitoring crop status and early warning systems. However, the vast majority of these assessments are qualitative and subjective, and thus difficult to use in quantitative applications. We show that the US Department of Agriculture Crop Progress and Condition survey data can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is robust to the subjective nature of the original data. This allows for the use of statistical models to predict crop status and yields, and provides earlier and more precise predictions than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of leveraging the vast network of “people as sensors” that exist in the form of crop experts to improve agricultural monitoring and management. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be mediated by the brain. However, the neural basis of language is still poorly understood. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This model provides a framework for understanding the neural basis of language and may lead to the development of new tools for understanding and treating language disorders.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to scientists and policy makers. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. This work is a step toward a better understanding of the role of soil respiration in the global carbon cycle and its response to climate change.

The molecular evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of the photosynthetic apparatus. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is not well understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This evolutionary process may be relevant to the evolution of other organelles. This work provides a framework for understanding the molecular evolution of the plastid genome and its role in the evolution of the photosynthetic apparatus. It also provides a model for the evolution of other organelles.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of water-scarce regions to climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is a step towards a better understanding of the role of anthropogenic climate change in the occurrence of extreme droughts. However, the results are limited by the coarse horizontal resolution of the model. This needs to be improved in future work. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the study of materials. However, the conditions under which they are formed are not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a naturally occurring icosahedral quasicrystal in red trinitite, the material that resulted from the first nuclear test explosion. This discovery has important implications for the origin of quasicrystals and for the study of the conditions under which they form. It also provides a link between the discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the first nuclear test explosion.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the presence of which is essential for the function of the chlorophyll pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron enzyme. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. A diiron enzyme in Rubrivivax gelatinosus is required for photosynthesis, whereas alphaproteobacterial cyclases require a newly discovered protein that we term BciE, encoded by a gene conserved in these organisms. These data delineate three classes of diiron cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants

Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was phase specific and was regulated by different glial cell types. We also found that ASK1 signaling in microglia was critical for the generation and maintenance of disease. Our findings suggest that ASK1 signaling in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in recent decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. The probability that precipitation deficits are also warm has increased, and we conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions. This conclusion is consistent with the fact that the 2012–2014 drought was preceded by several years of warm conditions. Our results suggest that the probability of drought will continue to increase in the future, and that adaptation efforts should focus on reducing the impacts of warm–dry conditions. This conclusion is particularly important in California, where the probability of drought is now very high.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests a potential therapeutic target. This work is the first to our knowledge to examine the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. It is also the first to our knowledge to examine the extent to which individual differences in reaction to news content may be related to personality. Results suggest that there is considerable individual-level variation in the extent to which people react to news content, and that this variation may be related to personality. In addition, results suggest that the extent to which people react to news content may be related to the prevalence of negativity biases in their culture. Taken together, these results suggest that the news media may be playing a role in the prevalence of negativity biases in the world.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, and show that they all result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel in vitro and in vivo. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to study the spread of aggregates in the brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We show that the release of aggregates requires active transport and that the spreading of aggregates is noncell autonomous. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in the brain and suggest that the release of aggregates is an important element of disease progression. This model may be useful for the development of new therapeutics for neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immune privileged, which is believed to be a key factor in the maintenance of the bat–virus–host cycle. However, the immunosuppressant protein (MTX) in bats has not been identified. Here, we identified MTX in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and characterized its immunosuppressant function. MTX was found to be highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, which is the first report of an immunosuppressant protein in bats. MTX inhibited the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitated viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the immune system of bats and the potential role of MTX in the bat–virus–host cycle. Cancer cells have a number of metabolic adaptations that allow them to grow despite the presence of DNA-damaging chemotherapy drugs. One such metabolic adaptation is the ability to use serine as a one-carbon donor. Serine is a precursor of the one-carbon units required for the synthesis of purine and thymidine, two essential building blocks of DNA. We have developed a series of small molecules that inhibit the enzyme that converts serine to glycine, a one-carbon donor. We show that these inhibitors are effective in blocking colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that these inhibitors are effective in blocking the growth of a subset of B-cell cancers, but not in blocking the growth of a different subset of B-cell cancers. Thus, these inhibitors may be useful in treating some B-cell cancers, but not others.

The presence of proteins that are supersaturated in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS suggests that these proteins are prone to aggregation. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions of mutant SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a unifying hypothesis for the formation of inclusion bodies in ALS. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystal system is a promising platform for exploring many-body physics in a 2D geometry. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the origin of the aquatic flowering plants is even less understood. The research presented here focuses on Montsechia, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. The study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens of Montsechia reveals that it is sister to Ceratophyllum, an aquatic plant. Montsechia is the earliest known aquatic angiosperm, and its discovery raises questions about the early diversification of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is often inferred from the analysis of extant sequences. However, viruses are known to evolve rapidly, and it is therefore important to also study ancient viral sequences. Here we present 10 ancient B19V sequences from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that viruses have been circulating for a long time in the past, and that we should be able to find ancient viral sequences in archaeological remains. This may be important for the study of ancient viruses in the future. (Show more)

The rate of sea level rise is one of the most visible and contentious aspects of climate change. The rate of acceleration of sea level is also an important indicator of the causes of sea level rise. We use a 25-y time series of satellite altimeter data to estimate the acceleration of global mean sea level. We find that the acceleration is statistically significant and is consistent with the climate-change–driven acceleration. This result provides a more precise estimate of the rate of sea level rise and the rate of acceleration than previous estimates. The results also provide a more precise estimate of the rate of acceleration of global mean sea level than previous estimates.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that pain has increased more rapidly with age for those born earlier in the 20th century than for those born later. This pattern is seen across the education spectrum for those with less education, but not for those with a bachelor’s degree. The erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is reflected in the erosion of working-class pain.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a critical piece of information for understanding enzyme function. However, the structure of this complex is difficult to obtain by X-ray crystallography because the substrate is often too flexible to form a stable crystal lattice. Here, we show how the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex can be obtained by combining solid-state NMR and X-ray crystallography. This integrated approach provides a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the enzyme–substrate complex, including the location of the protonated and deprotonated states of ionizable residues, the tautomeric states of amino acid side chains, and the location of crystallographic waters. This integrated approach is a powerful tool for understanding enzyme function.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the further development of remdesivir as a treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses. It may also be considered for a wider range of viruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of remdesivir in the treatment of viral diseases caused by enveloped viruses. The results may also be relevant for the development of antiviral treatments for other diseases caused by enveloped viruses.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by nature to regulate the growth and health of the associated organisms. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan to a symbiotic bacterium is sufficient to regulate the persistence of the entire symbiosis. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont only at night, when the host squid is active and the symbiont is producing light. This glycan-catabolizing activity is required for the periodic acidification of the crypts, which increases the availability of oxygen to the symbionts. This study provides a mechanistic link between glycan provision and the regulation of the health of the symbiotic system. It also suggests that other hosts may use this strategy to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in middle schools by changing the way teachers think about discipline. This change in mindset is associated with a reduction in suspensions and an increase in students’ respect for teachers. This study has implications for the future of school discipline, which is a major source of inequality in the US.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a large influence on these emissions, and it is therefore important to understand how to change people’s food choices to reduce these emissions. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria by 50% increased the proportion of vegetarian meals selected by 14.5 percentage points. This increase was not accompanied by a decrease in overall meal sales, suggesting that this change could be implemented in a way that does not lead to rebound effects. This study provides evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. This study also provides a model for how to conduct large-scale field studies to examine the impact of interventions on population-level behavior. This model can be applied to other areas of behavior change.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We applied quantitative proteomics to a collection of six oncogenes and found that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface proteome in cancer. This work also provides a resource for the cancer research community to use as a starting point for their own studies. The data are available at ProteomeXchange with identifier PXD018656. In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or electoral outcomes. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is not a panacea for the problems of election administration. Rather, it is a tool that can be used to improve the efficiency of the electoral process. Our findings also suggest that the electoral system is more important than the method of voting in determining the outcome of elections.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to millions of deaths worldwide. The virus has been shown to evade the host immune system and to interfere with the host antiviral response. In this work, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This work provides a molecular understanding of how SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 may interfere with the host immune response. This knowledge can be used to develop new therapeutics to combat the pandemic. Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia triggers cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the pathophysiology of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. It also provides a rationale for the use of CRFR1 antagonists in the treatment of cerebral edema. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The scientific enterprise is in the midst of a revolution. The amount of data being collected is growing exponentially, and the sophistication of the statistical methods being used to analyze these data is growing exponentially as well. This paper describes a new challenge that arises in this environment. We describe a way of thinking about this challenge and illustrate it with a few examples. We hope that this will stimulate further research in this area.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we found that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the differentiation of human adult skin fibroblasts into endothelial cells. This finding provides a new strategy for the generation of endothelial cells and the development of vascular networks. Furthermore, ETV2-induced endothelial cells can improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model. This study provides a new strategy for the treatment of ischemic disorders. The creation of ETV2-induced endothelial cells provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. (Show more)

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened a new field of research in the field of RTK biology. In this study, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also show that the zebrafish genome contains three genes that encode ligands of Alk and Ltk. These ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. In addition, we demonstrate that these ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a unique model system to study the physiological function of augmentor ligands and their link to Ltk. The role of STING in β-cell function and insulin secretion is unknown. Herein, we found that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion. STING deficiency in β-cells decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. STING deficiency in β-cells also led to down-regulation of Pax6, which is required for GSIS. These findings establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of type 2 diabetes. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual epidemics and occasional pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion. This mechanism is essential for optimal viral replication. We also identified a sequence-dependent interaction between the viral RNA segments, which favors copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses is limited. This study provides a molecular understanding of the packaging process of influenza A viruses. It also provides a basis for the development of antiviral strategies. Atherosclerotic lesions are characterized by a complex interplay between the local hemodynamic environment and the endothelial phenotype. The focal nature of atherosclerotic lesions suggests an important role of local hemodynamic environment. Recent studies have demonstrated significant roles of Yes-associated protein (YAP) and transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a significant threat to human life and property, as well as a major contributor to carbon emissions. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results suggest that actions to reduce fire risk and associated hazards should focus on reducing the role of humans in starting wildfires.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical processes that shape urban change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This study is expected to contribute to the conservation of biodiversity and the sustainable use of natural resources. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the dynamics of ZIKV within the host are likely to play an important role. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and that the eclipse phase for ZIKV is short. We also estimate the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime. Finally, we assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the dynamics of ZIKV in the host. Our results can help guide the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon in which corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of reef-building capacity. The underlying causes of this breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis are still debated. Here, we show that the breakdown of the symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling, which is a consequence of the heat stress response of the coral host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the body from the environment. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also a critical regulator of the microbiome. We found that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors. These tumors lead to the dysregulation of the microbiome, which in turn leads to the development of tumors. Our study highlights the importance of maintaining the balance between tumor growth and microbiome regulation. It also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. This study has implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer development and progression. It also provides a framework for developing strategies to control tumor growth and maintain host–microbe homeostasis. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may lead to the emergence of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Finally, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This study

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is marked by a rapid warming of the climate. This study shows that the start of this warming was caused by a volcanic eruption. The eruption of Mount Takahe in West Antarctica is shown to have caused stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn led to a warming of the Southern Hemisphere. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can have a large impact on climate. This is important for understanding the climate system and the role of humans in the climate system.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that most catches come from regions with high stress levels. We also show that inland fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poorest people. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to identify areas where inland fisheries are most at risk from overfishing and degradation, and thus where conservation and management efforts should be prioritized. This analysis can also be used to inform environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the regenerative capacity is limited, and regeneration is often unsuccessful. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This finding suggests that the molecular mechanisms controlling regeneration are more complex than previously thought. We also uncover a previously unknown form of ectopic axon outgrowth that is triggered by sensory activity and is linked to a form of endogenous regeneration in the same neuron type. These findings provide a unique platform for the discovery of genes that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the nervous system. They also suggest that the mammalian nervous system is more plastic than previously thought, and that the regenerative capacity of the nervous system can be enhanced. This is an important consideration in the context of neurodegenerative diseases.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions experiencing no recombination at all. We also find that recombination is more likely to occur at the start of genes than in the middle or at the end of genes. These results provide a detailed view of recombination in a flowering plant and may be relevant to the evolution of recombination in other organisms.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal reflecting the activity of a large number of brain regions. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of networks of functionally related regions, which are hypothesized to reflect the organization of the brain in health and disease. However, the number of networks is not fixed, and the number of regions in each network is not constant. Here, we show that the organization of the brain can be mapped by a small number of metabolically reproducible networks, which are stable over time. These networks can be used to assess the organization of the brain in health and disease. This approach can be used to monitor the effects of disease on the brain, and to assess the efficacy of treatment.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation initiation and is found on all mRNAs that are translated in the cell. In addition to the cap, there are other modifications of the 5′ end of mRNA, including the 7-methylguanosine cap in ribosomal RNA and the 5′ monophosphate cap in transfer RNA. Here we describe a third modification, the 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. The presence of this cap suggests that NAD+ is involved in the regulation of gene expression.

The epigenetic regulation of gene expression is a promising target for the treatment of diabetes complications. We found that DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist over time in people with diabetes, supporting an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides evidence that epigenetic changes in diabetes may be reversible. This is an important finding, as it suggests that epigenetic changes may be reversed by the treatment of diabetes.

The role of the fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies.
