Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high risk of relapse. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the gut microbiota is altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and that it may be a target for the management of the disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not well understood, and the role of nitrogenous compounds in tomato fruit flavor is unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the biosynthesis of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor and lays the foundation for the development of improved cultivars. (Show more)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to reflect different aspects of space. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is not well understood. Here, we used a novel method to image the activity and anatomy of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode the spatial map, are anatomically distinct from other cell types, and that they are strongly coupled among themselves. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of the MEC and its cell types and will be useful for understanding the function of the MEC in navigation. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. This study provides a unique example of flowering regulation in a plant system.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We demonstrate that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides a detailed view of the anatomy of the dopamine-containing nigral system and may have implications for understanding the pathophysiology of Parkinson’s disease and other disorders. This study also provides a model for the analysis of other systems in the brain. We are constantly interacting with others, and we often judge the quality of our interactions by how well we feel connected. But how do we know when we feel connected? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. We found that people feel more connected to the degree that their partner responds quickly to them, and that this signal is used by third-party listeners to judge the quality of the interaction. This finding suggests that we are constantly judging the quality of our interactions, and that we are constantly being judged by others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate and are characterized by unique electrophysiological properties. The SAN is composed of a small number of SANCs that are distributed in a small area. The mechanisms that regulate SAN automaticity are not well understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is selectively expressed in SANCs and plays a key role in regulating SAN automaticity. Our results reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate SAN automaticity. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory and antiinflammatory cytokines. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage activation.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be mediated by the brain. However, the neural basis of language is still poorly understood. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This model provides a framework for understanding the neural basis of language and may help to explain the emergence of language as a complex cognitive system.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for plant cell internalization and gene silencing. This work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biology.

Eutrophication is a major threat to aquatic ecosystems worldwide, driven largely by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small tributaries largely unmonitored. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large water bodies, especially in nearshore areas. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to small watersheds, which are often overlooked in watershed management plans. This could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. Our study also highlights the importance of bioavailability in determining the potential for nutrients to fuel algal blooms. This is especially important in large water bodies, where the nutrient-enriched plumes can become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to small watersheds, which are often overlooked in watershed management plans. This could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems. We also find that the dynamics of the network are sensitive to the details of the environmental forcing, and that the system can exhibit a rich variety of behaviors depending on the details of the forcing. This work provides a simple example of how the dynamics of a simple chemical network can be strongly influenced by the details of the environment. This is an important step toward understanding the role of the environment in the dynamics of complex systems.

The mechanisms by which antibodies can cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that antibodies against the NMDA receptor can change the intrinsic dynamics of the brain, making it more susceptible to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This mechanism may explain the diverse range of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with autoimmune encephalitis. Our findings may also help to explain the effects of other antibodies on the brain, such as those used in multiple sclerosis. This work offers mechanistic insights into the effects of antibodies on the brain. It may also help to explain the effects of other antibodies on the brain.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying these events. Here, we use a combination of proxies and modeling to identify and quantify an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. The event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean and to anoxia of the ocean floor. We also show that this event was linked to a warming of the ocean and that this warming was associated with enhanced nutrient fluxes. These results provide insights into the mechanisms that control the timing and magnitude of abrupt climate change. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Nevertheless, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. This study is a first step in understanding the impact of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, the results are limited to the Indonesian context and do not address the impact of certification on deforestation in other commodities or countries. Future studies should address these limitations

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis. It is conserved from bacteria to humans. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is difficult to study in humans because of its complexity and the lack of a human model organism. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an organism is often a defining characteristic. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In some species, multiple alleles of a single gene determine sex, and in others, different alleles of the same gene do not produce males or females. Here we show that the sex of a fish can be determined by multiple alleles of a single gene, and we show that this system can produce a variety of sex phenotypes. This system provides a unique context for understanding the causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct but related processes: accumulation of toxic reactive oxygen species- and lipid-derived species and depletion of essential nutrients. In this study, we show that the nutrient iron (Fe) is a key player in these processes. We demonstrate that the accumulation of toxic species is reduced in mice with reduced Fe levels. This reduction is mediated by the Fe chelator deferiprone, which decreases the oxidation and degradation of a toxic species, A2E, in the presence of light. These findings have implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly, and other retinal diseases. Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of food webs. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type can evolve into specialists on other prey types. These findings suggest that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentilla and their nematocysts. The evolutionary history of siphonophore specialization helps build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. This work contributes to the development of a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution.

The discovery of a hominin hand from East Africa ∼1.42 My old provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the modern human hand. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This discovery also provides a new handle on the evolution of the human hand in the Middle Pleistocene. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT that blocks tumor growth in mice. We have also identified a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is notoriously resistant to therapy. These findings provide a rationale for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a new class of cancer therapeutics. The role of forests in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers who are seeking to improve people’s diets and nutrition security, as well as for conservationists who are seeking to balance conservation and development goals.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of modern agriculture, allowing for the expansion of arable land and food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
